citations.narrative:
The licensee is currently conducting regulated activity but has exceeded the maximum number of animals allowed under
their license. Licenses issued under the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) are issued for a specific number of animals. This
licensee is authorized for a maximum number of 50 animals but currently is housing 58 regulated animals, making the
current license invalid. The birth of 11 skunk kits on 02-May-2023 caused the facility to exceed the maximum number of
animals authorized for the facility. There are several other animals at the facility that are currently bred and expected to
give birth shortly including: 3 striped skunk and 8 ferrets. In addition, there are 5 female sugar gliders and 1 female
chinchilla that may be bred since they are housed in pairs. Licensees demonstrate compliance with the AWA during their
pre-license inspection and those licenses are issued based on the numbers and types of animals at that time. Significant
increases in animals can exceed the capacity of the facility to ensure adequate care is provided to the animals. Licensees
are required to reapply and obtain a new license before any change that results in more than the authorized number of
animals. Correct by applying for and obtaining a new license before any additional regulated activity can occur or by
reducing the number of animals at the facility below the maximum authorized number under the current license.
Regulated activities must be discontinued until a valid active license is in place. Correct by 04-May-2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
